So it[.] a little complicated, and there[.] probably someone who can answer this better than I can but it[.] been 7 hours and no one has helped you out yet. So here goes. 

Global Studies is more of an umbrella-department-type-of-thing where you have to pick between 4 different majors: global development, public health, the environment, or security and justice. I think that global development is the most popular one of the four. It[.] super liberal_arts-y in that it[.] very inter-disciplinary and is all about how countries advance themselves, create culture, stuff like that. It[.] also a competitive major so not everyone who applies will get in. 

The politics department is also an umbrella-department-sort-of-thing and is divided into two majors: foreign affairs and government (we don't really have "political science," but there is a pretty comprehensive politics honors major). Foreign affairs and government are pretty similar, you just take a few more classes related whichever one you pick. Both are "non-competitive" majors so you really just have to take the prerequisites and declare. 

Political and social thought (PST) is pretty liberal_artsy because it[.] all about creating your own focus. It[.] also a competitive major. 

If you're really interested in IR and poli-sci, I think that the foreign affairs major would be the way to go. 

**Helpful links:**

[Global Studies](http://globalstudies. virginia. edu/)

[Politics](http://politics. virginia. edu/our-two-majors/)

[PST](https://pages. shanti. virginia. edu/pst/)

A really helpful thing to do would be to go to these websites and find out what classes are required for each major. Then go to [Lou[.] List](https://rabi. phys. virginia. edu/mySIS/CS2/), search for the classes, and read the descriptions. See if those are the sorts of classes that will interest you.
